title: Apply for your first adult passport

details.description: When you can apply for your first adult British passport, how long it takes, costs and how to do it

parts.title: Overview
parts.body:
You can apply for your first adult British passport if you’re aged 16 or over and one of the following:

  • a British citizen
  • a British overseas territories citizen
  • a British subject
  • a British national (overseas)
  • a British protected person

You can get more information about eligibility for a British passport.

If you’re outside the UK, you must apply to the Foreign and Commonwealth Office.

If you’ve had a child passport before, follow the process for renewing your passport to get your first adult one.

How long it takes

It takes at least 6 weeks to get your first UK adult passport.

The Identity and Passport Service may ask to interview you as part of the application process.

Cost

It costs £72.50 to apply for your first adult passport or £81.25 if you use the Post Office Check & Send service.

parts.title: Documents you must send with your application
parts.body:
You must send original documents that prove your identity as part of your application. The documents you need to send depend on your circumstances.

Photocopies, certified copies or laminated documents won’t be accepted - you must send originals.

How your documents will be sent back

Your documents will be sent back through the normal post.

You can pay an extra £3 to get your supporting documents sent back to you via secure delivery when you application has been processed.

Choose this service on your application form if you want to use it.

Born or adopted in the UK

Before 1 January 1983

You must send your birth or adoption certificate.

On or after 1 January 1983

You must send your birth or adoption certificate and either:

  • your mother’s or father’s UK birth certificate, Home Office certificate of registration/naturalisation, a British passport belonging to one of your parents that was valid when you were born or a British passport number for either parent (which you must put in section 4 of the application form)
  • evidence of one of your parents’ immigration status in the UK at the time of your birth (eg a foreign passport belonging to one of your parents that was valid when you were born)

If you send documents related to your father, you must also send your parents’ marriage certificate (unless you were born or adopted on or after 1 July 2006 or adopted by a same-sex couple).

Born outside the UK

You have a certificate of naturalisation or registration

You must send both:

  • your naturalisation or registration certificate
  • the passport you used to come into the UK or foreign passport you’re included on

Citizen of a British overseas territory - born before 1 January 1983

You must send both:

  • your birth certificate
  • your current passport
  • the passport you used to come into the UK or foreign passport you’re included on

Born before 1 January 1983 and your father was born in the UK

You must send:

  • your full birth certificate showing your parents’ details
  • your father’s birth certificate
  • your parents’ marriage certificate
  • the passport you used to come into the UK or foreign passport you’re included on

Born on or after 1 January 1983

You must send:

  • your full birth certificate showing your parents’ details
  • the passport you used to come into the UK or any foreign passport that you are included on

You must also send evidence of one parent’s British nationality. This can be their UK birth or adoption, naturalisation or registration certificate.

If these documents are about your father, you must include the marriage certificate when he married your mother - unless you were born on or after 1 July 2006.

Other circumstances and more advice

If your circumstances aren’t listed above, or you want more advice, read the guidance booklet on applying for a passport.

Download ‘Applying for a passport’ (PDF, 495KB)

parts.title: The application form
parts.body:
You can:

  • fill in the form online - the Identity and Passport Service (IPS) will post it back to you to check and sign
  • get one from a Post Office that offers the Post Office Check & Send service
  • call the Passport Adviceline and get them to post you one

Passport Adviceline

Telephone: 0300 222 0000
Textphone: 0300 222 0222
Text Relay: 18001 0300 222 0000
Monday to Friday, 8am to 8pm
Saturday, Sunday and public holidays, 9am to 5.30pm

Help filling in the form

The form comes with notes to help you fill it in. You can download a copy of the notes.

Download ‘Applying for a passport’ (PDF, 495KB)

Photos and countersignatories

You must include with your application 2 identical photos of yourself.

Follow the rules about passport photos or your application may be rejected.

You must get someone to sign (‘countersign’) your application form and 1 of your photos to prove your identity.

Check who can sign and what they have to do.

Send your application

You can either:

  • use the Post Office Check & Send service
  • post your application using the pre-printed envelope that comes with the form (include your photos and supporting documents)

If you post your application - payment

You can either:

  • fill in your credit or debit card details on the payment form in the ‘Applying for a passport’ guidance notes that come with the form
  • include a cheque or postal order payable to ‘Identity and Passport Service’

What happens next

The Identity and Passport Service (IPS) will contact you to arrange an interview.

parts.title: Your passport interview
parts.body:
The Identity and Passport Service (IPS) will write to you. When you get the letter, phone them to make an appointment for an interview at one of their offices.

You can choose an office that’s convenient for you to travel to, but you may not be able to make an appointment at the exact time or date you want.

These IPS offices are for interviews only - they can’t give you a passport.

If you live in a remote area, the IPS may be able to arrange an interview close to you. Ask when you phone to make an appointment.

If you were born on or before 2 September 1929, you may not need an identity interview. The IPS will tell you when they are dealing with your application.

Your interview

The interview will take about 30 minutes.

You’ll be asked to confirm facts about yourself that someone trying to steal your identity may not know.

The IPS destroys any personal information used in the interview shortly after the passport is issued.

After your interview

The IPS will continue with your application. Your new passport will be sent to your home address. You may need to sign for it.

If you want to check your application’s progress, call the Passport Adviceline - you can do this 2 weeks after you’ve made your application.

When you call, you need either:

  • the barcode number from your application form
  • the number on your receipt if you used Check & Send or applied at a Passport Customer Service Centre

Passport Adviceline

Telephone: 0300 222 0000
Textphone: 0300 222 0222
Text Relay: 18001 0300 222 0000
Monday to Friday, 8am to 8pm
Saturday, Sunday and public holidays, 9am to 5.30pm
